source.title: Optimizing the spacing between extraction trails in commercial thinning

machines.skidder_two_phase: Same Timberjack 240 operated as the second-phase extractor

notes: Road-spacing experiments compared $100/m building costs vs. extraction distances from 50–650 m.
Appendix 2 published delay-free productivity regressions relating extraction distance (m) to m³/PMH0 for both the forwarder and cable skidder scenarios.
Full-tree scenario included lop-and-scatter delays because feller-buncher and skidder worked as an integrated crew; the two-phase scenario isolated the extraction skidder once felling was decoupled.
Regression derived from Valmet 646 shortwood forwarder operating on 40 m trail spacing.
Report recommends keeping forwarding distances below 550 m when road costs stay under $12,000/km in similar stands.
Semi-mechanized crew (feller-buncher + skidder) where the skidder waited for the buncher at longer distances.
Use when modelling lop-and-scatter thinning where the skidder’s delays include felling coordination.
Represents the second phase after felling/slashing crews pre-bunched stems to trails.
Productivity declines logarithmically once trails exceed ~220 m, matching the report’s guidance to cap spacing at 200–250 m.
